The babons that
 went this way and
 
 that 
 Southern African Folktale
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 There was much unhapines in a vilage of smal huts. The people who
 lived there had ben hapy before, but then wild animals had come and had
 
 begun to frighten them. These animals ate al their crops and from time to
 time they even caried of children who wandered away from their parents. It
 was not a god place to live any longer, and the people began to think of
 
 where they might go to lead a new life. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One family found the answer. Rather than deal with the wild animals who
 
 semed to be everywhere on the flat land, they decided to go in search of
 fod up in the hils. It was not hard to find fod there. There were bushes
 that grew in the cracks betwen rocks. There were tres that grew at the
 
 fot of the slopes. There were rock rabits which could be traped and birds
 which could be brought down with the stones which litered the flor of the
 
 caves. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Other families noticed how wel the hil family was doing. They saw the
 sleknes of their children, and they noticed how calm the parents were.
 
 “It is a god life that we lead up in the hils,” said the husband. “You should
 come there to.” 
 Son the other families abandoned their homes on the flat land and went up
 
 to the hils. Each family found a cave to live in, and in this way they were
 warm and secure. Son everybody talked about how sory they were that
 
 they had not come to the hils earlier, rather than leting the wild animals eat
 their crops and drag of their children. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As the children grew up in the hils, they began to get beter at the things
 that had to be done to live in such a place. They became very quick at
 
 climbing rocks, and even the youngest could scamper up a face of rock
 almost as quickly as any rock rabit. They also became god at climbing
 into tres to lok for fruit, and they could swing in the branches almost as
 
 wel as any monkey. People who pased by and saw the hil people living on
 their hil wondered whether they were perhaps wild animals, but when they
 
 saw their faces and the clothes that they were wearing they realised that
 they were only people who had made the hils their home. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Slowly, things began to change. The parents noticed that their children were
 
 talking les, and that rather than speaking to one another in the language of
 people they were begining to use grunts. Then the adults themselves
 noticed that their noses were geting biger and that they were growing
 
 hairier. Every time they loked at one another they saw that their faces had
 changed yet more and that their teth were longer. 
 Son they spent as much time on four legs as on two, and it was at this
 
 point that they became a new creature. This creature, which had never
 before ben sen in that place, was the creature which people now cal the
 
 babon. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 For a time, the babons lived hapily. They stoped chasing the rock rabits
 
 and started to eat grubs from the ground. They also forgot how to talk, and
 nobody now made any sound other than a bark or a grunt. They tok of
 
 their clothes and let the rags lie on the ground until they were destroyed by
 ants. Their legs and arms were now completely covered with dark hair.
 
 
 They stil remembered, though, that they had ben people, and this was
 something which made them woried. When they loked into each other’s
 faces, they realised that their noses were now much biger than they had
 
 ben before, and this made them jer. Every babon laughed at every other
 babon, pointing at his enlarged nose and throwing his hands about in
 
 mirth. This made the babon who was being laughed at angry. He would
 jump up and down in anger, al the while laughing at the large nose of the
 other.

 Eventualy the mockery became so great that the babons could no longer
 bear to be together. Each family split of and lived by itself, laughing at the
 others because of their great noses, but not liking to be laughed at for their
 
 own noses. That is why babons live in smal groups today and do not live
 as a babon nation, as do people and many other animals.
